awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Material Design and Research Oriented Multidisciplinary Education: Amorphous to Nanocrystalline Electronic Materials with Applications to Thermoelectrics
awd_abstract_narration:
Amorphous based materials can possess fundamentally different electrical and thermal properties than crystalline or nanocrystalline forms of the same material. Although, amorphous materials have found applications and continue to show promise for modern technologies, charge carrier and phonon transport in these materials remain a point of dispute. The lack of long- and short-range order in amorphous materials leads to complicated interplay between structure and energy transport. In this project a novel class of electronic materials based on bulk amorphous structures in the form of amorphous-crystalline nanocomposites will be developed and their thermal and electrical properties will be tailored. The application will be focused on thermoelectric materials, but the results are expected to produce new science applicable to other functional materials including optical and magnetic materials. Parallel to the research endeavors, an educational plan will be implemented which incorporates and develops a new teaching initiative in the upper-division undergraduate curriculum, involves undergraduates in research, promotes student international collaborative research, exposes the field of energy materials to the general public, and provides a resource web-site for advanced thermoelectric material studies. The available resources in the Oklahoma Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (OK-LSAMP) and Multicultural Engineering Program (MEP) programs will be used for expanding the participation of minority students and the recruitment of high school students.

This research plan addresses the essential need for a physical description of charge and phonon transport in amorphous based materials, characterization of their structural dependencies, and application of this understanding to enhance the thermoelectric performance of amorphous and the more complex structure of amorphous-crystalline nanocomposite materials. The focus will be especially in the regime where the carriers energy remains at non-equilibrium state due to the consecutive passage through material domains with different equilibrium energy distribution of carriers. The multi-mode transport of charge carriers in extended and localized states in disordered multi component amorphous-crystalline nanocomposite structures will be addressed. This is a new scientific problem with many unresolved scientific questions. Further understanding of charge carrier and phonon transport in such amorphous based materials will directly impact their material design and offer novel material structures for electronic applications. Parallel to theoretical studies, an efficient and scalable top-down approach for synthesizing such structures will be developed. The material is processed in a single transversal mode microwave cavity that provides an extraordinary route to create a new state of amorphous materials in a rather quick and convenient way. The decrystallization process happens by merely subjecting the solid material to a strong E or H field in the cavity. The method results in in-situ formation of such structures, which is not possible by conventional bulk processing methods. This unique capability opens a new landscape for engineering non-equilibrium structures.

por.por_cntn:
This five-year career-development project integrated research, education, and outreach programs focusing on designing and developing novel electronic materials for energy applications. The outcomes of the project are briefly listed as follow:


1) Two comprehensive codes were developed to study the non-equilibrium transport of electrons and phonons at the interfaces. The codes are linked to DFT calculation for the bandstructure and phonon dispersion. In particular, we developed Monte Carlo and simulation codes based on the Coherent Potential Approximation (CPA) of the momentum and energy relaxation times at grain boundaries for both charge carriers and phonons in nanostructured materials. Next, the code was extended with the inclusion of the magnetic field and solving for thermomagnetic parameter effects.


2) An efficient and scalable top-down approach based on microwave in-situ sintering decrystallization for synthesizing amorphous to nanocrystalline multi-component bulk thermoelectric materials was developed and applied to various thermoelectric materials.  


3) P-type and n-type amorphous-crystalline nanocomposite thermoelectric materials based on Bi-Sb-Se-Te were engineered and developed to meet the wearable system requirements and to work efficiently for body heat harvesting. 


4) Fabricated rigid and flexible TEGs with both n-type and p-type nanocomposite legs with optimized metal contacts for both legs. Our works resulted in TEG technologies that have increased the power generated from body heat by ~2X compared to the previous state-of-the-art technologies and 4-7X times compared to the commercial TE  devices (Figure 1).  

 

5) For comparison with previous technologies, we fabricated a wristband harvester with a similar size as the Seiko Thermic watch and characterized it on the body (Figure 2). Our wristband power was about 300 ?W, 12X larger than the power from the Seiko Thermic watch (25 ?W). It is worth mentioning that the power was measured at the output of a CO TS boost convertor; therefore, the 300 ?W is the net available power. 


6) The enhancement in thermoelectric performance from the charge and phonon engineering has reached a plateau, mainly because charge carriers are bound to Pauli's expulsion principle and obey the Fermi-Dirac statistics. To surpass this limitation, we investigated Bosonic systems such as the spin-wave or magnons. This work resulted in the first demonstration of spin-driven thermoelectrics with zT > 1, where the spin effects surpass the electronic effect leading to over 300% improvement in zT (Figure 3). 

 

7) For the first time, we demonstrated that the drag thermopower in bipolar intrinsic semiconductor significantly suffers from the magnon bipolar carrier drag effect, which can reduce the drag thermopower to near zero at below the transition temperature.

 

8) To model the microwave effect in a chemical reaction, we developed a Monte Carlo code that can accept different physical models defined by the user for microwave reactions. The code was recently released to the public as an open-source on the PI's website https://research.ece.ncsu.edu/nanoengineering/monte-carlo-microwave-effects-in-reactions/ 


9) We investigated the MW interaction with several strongly correlated transition metal compounds with unpaired d-electrons, a.k.a. as Mott oxides, with nearly degenerate spin states. It was found that MW spin configuration plays a critical role in MW absorption. With increasing temperature when a crossover of different spin states occurs, the interaction of the material with MW can change dramatically. Therefore, the MW interaction with the spin states can increase (forward) or decrease (reverse) a reaction.


10) An education plan was implemented, which incorporated a new teaching initiative in the upper-division undergraduate curriculum, involved undergraduates in research, promoted student international collaborative research, exposed the field of energy materials to the general public, and provided a resource website for advanced thermoelectric material studies.
